elements.text: For this activity, you will need a ruler, a piece of chart paper, one red and one blue marker, and classroom objects for each child to measure (pencil, marker, paper clip, book, etc.). Draw a horizontal line across the bottom of the chart paper with the red marker, about two inches from the bottom.
Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
we talked about measuring and comparing how tall two characters were.
In this activity, you will practice using a ruler to mark how tall an object is. We will make a graph that shows how tall all of the objects are. Then we will compare the objects’ heights.
Place the chart paper on the table. Explain,
We’ll make our graph on this paper.
Give each child a different classroom object, and let them know that this is the object they will measure.

Guide the first child to lay an object on the chart paper so that the bottom is lined up with the red line. Help the child lay the ruler next to the object. Have the child point to or mark the top of the object, using the ruler as a guide. Then, using the ruler, draw a straight line with the blue marker from the child’s mark to the red line. Record the name of the object and the child’s name beneath the red line.
Help the children measure their objects.
Which object was the tallest? Which was the shortest? How can you tell?

Model measuring an object using the ruler before calling on the first child. You may wish to hold the graph perpendicular to the table to demonstrate that the measurement shows the object’s height even though it was flat on the table when you measured it.
As you call on each child to measure their object, ask,
Do you think your object is short or tall? Why?
Once a few children have measured, you could also ask,
Do you think your object will be taller or shorter than this object? Let’s find out!
means most. Provide sentence frames for discussing:

While you help one child measure her object, have the rest of the children measure their objects’ heights using Connecting Cubes. They can also use Connecting Cubes to measure their fingers, hands, or any other object.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
we talked about ways we can share what we think with others. We also talked about whether things on each page were tall or short.
Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

In this activity, I will show you Activity Cards with pictures on them. You will tell me whether you think the thing in the picture is tall or short. Then, you will share a time that you saw or used the thing in the picture.
Show children the first Activity Card. Ask whether the object or animal in the picture is tall or short.
are relative terms, so it is okay if children have a different answer than what is written on the back of the card. Encourage all children to explain their reasoning.
Invite children to share their personal experiences with the object or animal in the picture. For example:
Have you ever been inside a very tall building? Share that story with us!
Encourage children to tell their story using complete sentences and details.
Continue the activity until all of the Activity Cards have been shown and discussed.
Have children sort the Activity Cards into two piles: tall and short. Guide children to create a row with the tall cards and a different row for the short cards, creating a bar graph. Ask,
Are there more tall things or more short things? How can you tell?
Help children determine an object’s height if they can’t decide between tall and short. For example:
A fire hydrant is about as tall as a big dog. Do you think that’s tall or short?
You may also lift your hand above the ground to show how tall some items are.
As you show each Activity Card, also ask:
Are you taller or shorter than what’s in the picture?
After graphing, challenge children to order the cards by height of the objects pictured.

Children from different cultures, backgrounds, and places may have varied levels of familiarity with the objects and animals in the pictures. If children have never had an experience with one of the pictures, explain what the object or animal is and what it does or how it is used.

Give children ample time to collect their thoughts before sharing their prior experiences with the pictured objects. Have children share with a partner or you before sharing with the group. Children often feel more confident after rehearsing their responses with someone else before sharing them with the larger group.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

For this activity, you will need the height chart created in Theme 3, Week 3. You will also need a yard stick or measuring tape, crayons or colored pencils, yarn or ribbon, and a sticky note for each child.
we talked about how most of us get taller as we get older.
Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.
In this activity, we will measure how tall you are today. Then, we’ll look at the height chart we made earlier in the year and compare the heights. We will be able to see how much you’ve grown!
Tape the height chart to the wall. Give each child a sticky note, and have them write their name on it. Mark each child’s height next to their initial measurement.
How much do you think you’ve grown? Let’s measure you and find out! Then we will put your sticky note on the chart to show your height.

Have each child stand with their back to the chart. Tape a piece of yarn or ribbon to the chart representing each child’s height. Guide children to place their sticky notes at the top of their piece of yarn.
Use the yard stick or measuring tape to determine the height of each child in inches. Record the number on the sticky note as well.
Did you grow? Are you taller than you were at the beginning of the year? How can you tell? Can we tell who grew most?
Model determining how much a child grew. Point to the two sticky notes for a child. Say:
This new sticky note is higher on the wall than the first one. These numbers tell her height, and this number is bigger than this one. That means she grew taller!

Challenge children to practice reading the yard stick or measuring tape as you measure other children. As you measure one child, ask another to find the corresponding number on the yard stick or measuring tape that indicates the first child’s height.
. Use hand gestures as you compare height by holding your hand high or low and pointing to the sticky notes of the heights you are comparing.

Help children stay focused as you measure all of the children in the group by giving them Connecting Cubes and Two-Color Counters. Challenge children to build a Connecting Cube tower and then measure its height using Two-Color Counters placed end-to-end as the unit of measurement.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need sticky notes and a board or chart.
Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
we talked about the things we investigated and discovered this year.

In this activity, you will “investigate” your partner— you’ll ask a partner a question to learn something about them. Then, you will graph your partner’s answer. We’ll compare the group’s answers to discover new things about our friends!
Pair children with partners and have each child write their own name on a sticky note. Have partners ask each other a question about their lives, for example:
Does your partner have a pet? Investigate by asking your partner!
Give all partners time to ask each other the question and discuss their answers.
What was your partner’s answer? Does your partner have a pet?

Have partners place their partner’s sticky note on the chart to record the answer in the “pet” or “no pet” column. They should place sticky notes with the same answer in a column to create a bar graph.
Continue with different questions as time allows, graphing each question’s answers separately. Choose questions that have only two possible answers to make graphing easier.
What did we discover about our friends today? Do most of you have pets? How can you tell? What else did we discover?
Ask a child to be your partner and model recording the child’s answer on the chart or board. Help children read the graphs:
There are lots of sticky notes for this answer. There aren’t as many for this one. Which answer was said the most? What does that tell us?
Have children ask and answer open-ended questions, such as,
Create a bar graph with a bar for each answer, and challenge children to read it.

This activity requires varied vocabulary, and may be difficult for multilingual learners. Pair children with partners who speak the same home language, if possible. Try to choose questions that play to children’s vocabulary strengths. (For example, if a child knows a lot of vocabulary regarding siblings, but not as much regarding pets, ask instead,
Do you have a brother or sister?

Rather than having children place sticky notes on a chart, have them create each graph by placing Two-Color Counters on the table or floor in straight rows. When one graph is finished, discuss what new information was discovered before moving on to the next question, using the same counters to record answers.
